title: Psalms Chapter 145 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 145 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 145 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 145.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalm 145 according to the chapter heading?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalm 145 is introduced as 'David's Psalm of praise' in Psalms 145:1, indicating David as the author.

questions.question: What action does the psalmist promise to do every day in Psalms 145:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Bless and praise God's name
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:2 states that every day the psalmist will bless and praise God's name forever and ever.

questions.question: How does Psalm 145 describe the greatness of the LORD in verse 3?
questions.correctAnswer: Great and unsearchable
questions.explanation: Verse 3 says, 'Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; and his greatness is unsearchable.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 145:4, what will one generation do for another?
options: Praise God's works and declare His mighty acts
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God's works and declare His mighty acts
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:4 states that one generation shall praise God's works to another and declare His mighty acts.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted in Psalms 145:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious and full of compassion
questions.explanation: Verse 8 describes the LORD as gracious, full of compassion, slow to anger, and of great mercy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 145:9: 'The LORD is good to all: and his tender mercies are over all his ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: works
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:9 says that God's tender mercies are over all his works, showing His goodness to all.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 145:13, God's kingdom is everlasting and His dominion endures through all generations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:13 affirms that God's kingdom is everlasting and His dominion endures throughout all generations.

questions.question: What does the LORD do for those who fall, according to Psalms 145:14?
options: He upholds them and raises those bowed down
He sends angels to fight for them
questions.correctAnswer: He upholds them and raises those bowed down
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:14 states that the LORD upholds all that fall and raises up all who are bowed down.

questions.question: According to Psalms 145:15, what do the eyes of all do?
questions.correctAnswer: Wait upon the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 15 explains that the eyes of all wait upon the LORD, who gives them their food in due season.

questions.question: True or False: Psalm 145 says the LORD satisfies the desire of every living thing by opening His hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:16 states that God opens His hand and satisfies the desire of every living thing.

questions.question: What is said about the LORD's righteousness in Psalms 145:17?
options: He is righteous in all His ways and holy in all His works
He is righteous only to some people
questions.correctAnswer: He is righteous in all His ways and holy in all His works
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:17 declares that the LORD is righteous in all his ways and holy in all his works.

questions.question: According to Psalms 145:18, who is the LORD near to?
options: All that call upon Him in truth
questions.correctAnswer: All that call upon Him in truth
questions.explanation: Verse 18 says the LORD is near unto all who call upon Him in truth.

questions.question: What will the LORD do for those who fear Him according to Psalms 145:19?
options: Fulfil their desires, hear their cry, and save them
questions.correctAnswer: Fulfil their desires, hear their cry, and save them
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:19 states that God will fulfill the desire of those who fear Him, hear their cry, and save them.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 145:20, the LORD preserves all who love Him and destroys all the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:20 confirms that the LORD preserves all who love Him but destroys all the wicked.

questions.question: What will the psalmist's mouth speak according to Psalms 145:21?
questions.correctAnswer: Praise of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 21 states the psalmist's mouth shall speak the praise of the LORD.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 145 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 145 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 145, what biblical truth would you share about God's care in times of trouble?
options: God upholds those who fall and raises up those who are bowed down
God leaves us to face trials alone
God ignores the cries of believers
questions.correctAnswer: God upholds those who fall and raises up those who are bowed down
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:14 teaches that the LORD upholds all who fall and raises up those who are bowed down, showing His care and support in difficult times. This is supported by verses 18 and 19 which speak of God being near to those who call upon Him and hearing their cry.

questions.question: How does Psalms 145 encourage believers to maintain a habit of praise and prayer in their daily lives?
options: By blessing and praising God's name every day forever
By only praising God on special occasions
By praising only when feeling joyful
By relying on others to pray for them
questions.correctAnswer: By blessing and praising God's name every day forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:1-2 express a commitment to bless and praise God's name every day, emphasizing continuous devotion and prayer. This daily habit strengthens faith and trust in God.

questions.question: In teaching children and family about faith, what does Psalms 145 say about passing on knowledge of God's works?
options: One generation should praise and declare God's mighty acts to another
Each generation should keep God's works secret
Only parents need to know God's works
Children will learn about God naturally without teaching
questions.correctAnswer: One generation should praise and declare God's mighty acts to another
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:4 instructs that one generation shall praise God’s works and declare His mighty acts to the next, highlighting the importance of family and church teaching for spiritual growth.

questions.question: How should a believer respond to God's mercy and compassion in their personal devotion, according to Psalms 145?
options: By recognizing God as gracious, compassionate, slow to anger, and full of mercy
By expecting God to be quick to anger
By believing God is indifferent to human needs
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing God as gracious, compassionate, slow to anger, and full of mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:8 describes the LORD as gracious, full of compassion, slow to anger, and abundant in mercy, encouraging believers to trust in His loving character during personal devotion and prayer.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment and wants to trust God for daily provision. What truth from Psalms 145 can you share?
options: The eyes of all look to God, and He gives them their food at the proper time
God provides only for the righteous
Provision is uncertain and dependent on luck
questions.correctAnswer: The eyes of all look to God, and He gives them their food at the proper time
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:15 states that all eyes look to the LORD and He provides food in due season, teaching believers to trust God’s timing and provision in daily life.

questions.question: What does Psalms 145 teach about integrity and righteousness in God's ways and works?
options: The LORD is righteous and holy in all His ways and works
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is righteous and holy in all His ways and works
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:17 emphasizes that God is righteous and holy in all His ways and works, encouraging believers to pursue integrity and holiness in their own lives.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 145, how should believers approach prayer and calling on God?
options: Call upon God in truth, knowing He is near and hears their cries
Call on God only in emergencies
Avoid prayer because God is distant
questions.correctAnswer: Call upon God in truth, knowing He is near and hears their cries
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:18-19 teach that the LORD is near to all who call upon Him in truth and will fulfill the desires of those who fear Him and save them, encouraging sincere and faithful prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 145 instruct believers regarding generosity and God's provision for all living things?
options: God opens His hand and satisfies the desires of every living thing
Provision is only for certain people
God does not care for the needs of creation
questions.correctAnswer: God opens His hand and satisfies the desires of every living thing
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:16 describes God’s generous provision to satisfy every living thing, teaching believers to trust God’s abundant care and be generous themselves.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 145, God's kingdom is temporary and will eventually pass away.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:13 states that God's kingdom is everlasting and His dominion endures through all generations, affirming the eternal nature of His reign.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 145 teaches that God preserves all who love Him but destroys the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:20 declares that the LORD preserves all who love Him and will destroy all the wicked, emphasizing God's justice and protection for the faithful.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 145:7, believers should abundantly utter the memory of God's great ______ and sing of His righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: goodness
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:7 instructs believers to abundantly declare God's great goodness and sing of His righteousness, encouraging gratitude and praise.

questions.question: How does Psalms 145 encourage believers to witness to others about God's kingdom and power?
options: By speaking of the glory and power of God's kingdom and making known His mighty acts
By focusing only on personal blessings
questions.correctAnswer: By speaking of the glory and power of God's kingdom and making known His mighty acts
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:11-12 teaches that believers should speak of God's kingdom glory and power and make known His mighty acts to others, emphasizing evangelism and testimony.

questions.question: What attitude toward God’s greatness and majesty is modeled in Psalms 145 that believers should emulate?
options: Extolling, blessing, and declaring His wondrous works and majesty
questions.correctAnswer: Extolling, blessing, and declaring His wondrous works and majesty
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:1, 5, and 6 model a posture of praise and declaration of God's greatness and majesty, which believers are encouraged to imitate in worship and daily life.

questions.question: How can believers apply the truth of God's mercy and compassion from Psalms 145 in their relationships with others?
options: By showing grace, compassion, patience, and mercy as God does
By being quick to anger and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: By showing grace, compassion, patience, and mercy as God does
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:8 and 9 describe God's graciousness and mercy, inspiring believers to mirror these qualities in their interactions with others.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the call to spiritual discipline found in Psalms 145 regarding praise and devotion?
options: Continuously praising and blessing God’s name forever
Praising God only in times of need
questions.correctAnswer: Continuously praising and blessing God’s name forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:1-2 and 21 emphasize a lifelong commitment to praising and blessing God's name, showing the importance of consistent spiritual discipline.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 145 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 145.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 145 to emphasize the continuous praise of God across generations?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 145 uses parallelism to express the ongoing praise of God, as seen in verses like 4 and 7 where generational praise and memory of God's goodness are emphasized.

questions.question: In Psalms 145:8, which Hebrew concepts are reflected in the LORD being described as 'gracious, and full of compassion; slow to anger, and of great mercy'?
questions.correctAnswer: Chesed and Rachamim
questions.explanation: The terms 'gracious' and 'full of compassion' correspond to the Hebrew words Chesed (steadfast love) and Rachamim (mercy), highlighting God's covenantal loyalty and tender mercy.

questions.question: How does the theme of God's 'everlasting kingdom' in Psalms 145:13 relate to the Messianic prophecies found in the book of Daniel?
options: It anticipates an eternal dominion established by the Son of Man
It refers only to the Davidic monarchy's temporal reign
It is a metaphor for Israel's political independence
It contrasts with the transient kingdoms in Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates an eternal dominion established by the Son of Man
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:13's mention of an everlasting kingdom relates to Daniel 7:13-14, where the Son of Man receives an eternal kingdom, foreshadowing the Messianic reign.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the promise in Psalms 145:18 that 'The LORD is nigh unto all them that call upon him'?
questions.correctAnswer: Romans 10:13
questions.explanation: Romans 10:13 quotes Joel 2:32 but echoes the same promise as Psalms 145:18 that everyone who calls on the Lord will be saved and the Lord is near to them.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'thy tender mercies are over all his works' in Psalms 145:9 within the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It asserts God's universal care over all creation, contrasting pagan gods limited to nations
It implies God's selective mercy only to Israel
It denotes God's wrath hidden behind mercy
It is a poetic exaggeration with no theological weight
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts God's universal care over all creation, contrasting pagan gods limited to nations
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, gods often had limited domains; Psalms 145:9 emphasizes God's compassion extends to all creation universally, challenging those views.

questions.question: Identify the type of parallelism in the verse: 'The LORD is righteous in all his ways, and holy in all his works' (Psalms 145:17).
questions.correctAnswer: Synonymous parallelism
questions.explanation: Both lines affirm God's moral perfection in ways and works, repeating the same idea with different words, characteristic of synonymous parallelism.

questions.question: How does Psalms 145:14's depiction of God 'upholding all that fall' reflect the covenantal relationship between God and Israel?
options: It shows God's sustaining grace despite Israel's failures
It emphasizes divine judgment without mercy
It depicts God as indifferent to human frailty
It refers only to physical strength in battle
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's sustaining grace despite Israel's failures
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's faithfulness to support and restore those who falter, reflecting covenantal mercy and grace in Israel's history.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 145 repeatedly emphasizes God's justice as a primary attribute alongside His mercy and compassion.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:7 and 17 emphasize God's righteousness and justice, showing that alongside mercy, justice is a key divine attribute.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 145 foreshadows the universal scope of salvation later emphasized in the New Testament?
options: God's tender mercies over all His works
questions.correctAnswer: God's tender mercies over all His works
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:9's universal mercy anticipates the New Testament teaching of God's salvation extending to all nations and peoples.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'thy mouth shall speak the praise of the LORD' in Psalms 145:21 regarding ancient Israelite worship practices?
options: It reflects the verbal proclamation of God's praise in communal worship
It mandates silent meditation without speech
It forbids public praise and emphasizes private prayer
It prescribes only instrumental music without words
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the verbal proclamation of God's praise in communal worship
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the importance of vocal praise in Israel's worship tradition, showing how praising God was a communal and verbal act.

questions.question: In the structure of Psalms 145, how does the repetition of 'for ever and ever' in verses 1 and 2 serve the Psalm's overall message?
options: It emphasizes the eternal and unending nature of God's praise and kingdom
It indicates a limited period of worship
It is a common closing formula unrelated to the theme
It reflects a later editorial insertion
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the eternal and unending nature of God's praise and kingdom
questions.explanation: The repetition bookends the Psalm highlighting the perpetual nature of worship and God's everlasting reign, reinforcing the theme of eternity.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 145 explicitly connects God's provision with the needs of all living creatures, reflecting a universal sustainer role?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 145:16
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states 'Thou openest thine hand, and satisfiest the desire of every living thing,' emphasizing God's care for all creation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 145:19, God will fulfill the desires of those who ______ Him.
questions.correctAnswer: fear
questions.explanation: Verse 19 states 'He will fulfill the desire of them that fear him,' highlighting reverence as key to answered prayer.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 145 uses the imagery of 'eyes of all wait upon thee' to denote reliance on God?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 145:15
questions.explanation: Verse 15 depicts the eyes of all creatures waiting on God, illustrating universal dependence on His provision.

questions.question: What cultural or historical significance does the phrase 'The LORD preserveth all them that love him' (Psalms 145:20) convey about God's relationship with His people in the ancient Near East?
options: It affirms divine protection for covenant followers amidst hostile nations
It limits God's protection to Israel's kings only
It suggests God's indifference to human loyalty
It implies protection is earned by military strength
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms divine protection for covenant followers amidst hostile nations
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, divine protection was central; this verse assures God preserves those loyal to Him despite external threats.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 145 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 145 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 145, what attribute of God is emphasized as 'unsearchable'?
questions.correctAnswer: His greatness
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:3 states that the LORD's greatness is unsearchable, highlighting the infinite and incomprehensible nature of God's majesty. This aligns with passages like Romans 11:33, Job 11:7, Isaiah 40:28, and Jeremiah 32:17 which affirm God's infinite greatness and wisdom.

questions.question: What eternal aspect of God's kingdom is taught in Psalms 145?
questions.correctAnswer: It is an everlasting kingdom
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:13 declares God's kingdom as everlasting and His dominion enduring through all generations, emphasizing the eternal and sovereign rule of God. This doctrine is supported by Daniel 7:14, Luke 1:33, Revelation 11:15, and Isaiah 9:7.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes God's attitude toward anger as described in Psalms 145?
questions.correctAnswer: Slow to anger
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:8 characterizes the LORD as gracious, full of compassion, and slow to anger, underscoring His patience and mercy. This is consistent with Exodus 34:6, Numbers 14:18, Joel 2:13, and Jonah 4:2.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The LORD is ______ in all his ways, and holy in all his works.'
questions.correctAnswer: righteous
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:17 states that the LORD is righteous in all His ways and holy in all His works, affirming God's perfect justice and holiness. This is echoed in Deuteronomy 32:4, Isaiah 6:3, 1 John 1:5, and Romans 3:26.

questions.question: What does Psalms 145 say about God's provision for living creatures?
options: He opens His hand and satisfies the desire of every living thing
He provides only for His chosen people
He demands offerings in exchange for provision
He withholds provision to test faith
questions.correctAnswer: He opens His hand and satisfies the desire of every living thing
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:16 explains that God opens His hand and satisfies the desires of every living thing, teaching His universal providence. This truth is supported by Matthew 6:26, Acts 14:17, Psalm 104:27-28, and Job 38:41.

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes the relationship between God and those who call upon Him according to Psalms 145?
options: The LORD is near to all who call on Him in truth
God is distant and hard to find
He only answers the prayers of the righteous
He ignores the cries of the humble
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is near to all who call on Him in truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:18 emphasizes that the LORD is near to all who sincerely call upon Him, underscoring God's accessibility and faithfulness in prayer. This is consistent with Jeremiah 29:12, Isaiah 65:24, Hebrews 4:16, and 1 John 5:14.

questions.question: What does Psalms 145 teach about God's attitude toward those who love Him?
options: He preserves all who love Him
He punishes all who love Him
He is indifferent to those who love Him
He temporarily blesses those who love Him
questions.correctAnswer: He preserves all who love Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:20 states that the LORD preserves all who love Him, affirming God's protective care over His beloved. This doctrine aligns with Romans 8:28-39, Psalm 31:23, John 10:28-29, and 2 Thessalonians 3:3.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a theme explicitly mentioned in Psalms 145?
questions.correctAnswer: The fall of angels
questions.explanation: While Psalms 145 highlights God's righteousness (v.17), mercy (v.8-9), and kingdom (v.11-13), it does not mention the fall of angels. This theme is found elsewhere in Scripture like Isaiah 14:12-15 and Revelation 12:7-9.

questions.question: How does Psalms 145 describe the transmission of God's praise across generations?
options: One generation shall praise His works to another
Praise is only for the current generation
Only priests are to praise God
Praise is limited to personal experience
questions.correctAnswer: One generation shall praise His works to another
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:4 teaches that praise of God's works is passed from one generation to another, emphasizing the continuity of worship and testimony. This is echoed in Deuteronomy 6:7, Psalm 78:4, Joel 1:3, and 2 Timothy 2:2.

questions.question: What does Psalms 145 say about God's response to the cries of those who fear Him?
options: He hears their cry and will save them
questions.correctAnswer: He hears their cry and will save them
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:19 affirms that God hears the cries of those who fear Him and saves them, reflecting His responsiveness and salvation. This is consistent with Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 41:10, Jonah 2:2, and Romans 10:13.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The eyes of all wait upon thee; and thou givest them their ______ in due season.'
questions.correctAnswer: meat
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:15 states that all creatures look to God for provision and He gives them their meat in due season, illustrating God's faithful providence. Supporting texts include Matthew 6:26, Psalm 104:27-28, and Job 38:41.

questions.question: What is the proper human response to God's works according to Psalms 145?
options: To praise and bless His name forever
questions.correctAnswer: To praise and bless His name forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:1-2 and 21 emphasize that humans should extol, bless, and praise God's name forever, showing continual worship. This is consistent with Revelation 5:13, Psalm 150:6, Hebrews 13:15, and Philippians 4:4.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 145 describes God's compassion toward humanity?
questions.correctAnswer: Full of compassion
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:8 describes the LORD as 'full of compassion,' highlighting His tender mercy. This attribute is also emphasized in Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4, Titus 3:5, and Psalm 103:13.

questions.question: According to Psalms 145, what will all the works of God do?
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:10 teaches that all God's works shall praise Him, reflecting creation's worship. This theme resonates with Psalm 19:1, Romans 1:20, Hebrews 1:3, and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What does Psalms 145 teach about the declaration of God's mighty acts?
options: They are to be made known to the sons of men
They are to be kept secret
questions.correctAnswer: They are to be made known to the sons of men
questions.explanation: Psalms 145:12 highlights that God's mighty acts and glorious majesty are proclaimed to humanity, emphasizing evangelism and testimony. This is consistent with Psalm 96:3, Acts 1:8, Isaiah 12:4, and Romans 10:17.
